ACLU of Montana lawsuit moves forward.
 ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌

Dear ##SM_RULE_360 Email Salutation##,

Back in 2015, we filed a lawsuit on behalf of Disability Rights Montana to stop the inhumane and unconstitutional treatment of prisoners with mental illnesses at the Montana State Prison. When the district court dismissed the case, we fought back.

In good news to those who continue to endure horrific treatment at the Montana State Prison, last week, the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals reversed the lower court decision that had dismissed the case. In its opinion, the Ninth Circuit held that the case describes "horrific treatment of prisoners."

We will continue to fight on behalf of the individuals with mental illnesses at MSP — about 20 percent of the prison's population. They are regularly locked in solitary confinement for months or even years and then punished for behavior that is a manifestation of their illness. MSP fails to diagnose people accurately, has no standards to determine whether punishments will be harmful to a person's mental health, and fails to provide proper medication and treatment to those with serious mental illness. When people do obtain an evaluation, a visit with a psychiatrist, or medication, those services, and treatments are often severely delayed. The failure of the DOC to provide constitutionally guaranteed mental health treatment has led to deteriorating mental health, extreme self-harm, and suicide.

Some people with mental health illnesses are put on "Behavior Management Plans" (BMP) where they are kept in 24-hour isolation, stripped from their clothes, and are given just a mattress, blanket, and smock. They are fed a meal of nutraloaf (a tasteless loaf) on a paper towel and are not allowed any running water in their cell. In some cases, the person does not have access to a toilet, and instead must go to the bathroom through a grate on the floor. Many of the individuals are placed on BMPs when the lack of appropriate care exacerbates their mental illness. In fact, some of the mental health staff at the prison have encouraged the use of BMPs instead of ensuring that the people get constitutionally adequate care. The Montana State Prison's most common response to a person expressing thoughts of suicide is to place them on a BMP.

People with serious mental illnesses are being forced into horrific and unconstitutional conditions instead of getting the necessary treatment that the state has a duty to provide.

We sued to end this barbaric practice. The state must do better. Last week's Ninth Circuit opinion is an important step forward in this work.

Thanks for sticking with us,

ACLU of Montana
